docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a front-page article and a column by David Brooks.

headline.main: The Debate Over the Birth Control Rule
headline.print_headline: The Debate Over the Birth Control Rule

docs.abstract: Catholic hospitals are now claiming a special right to conscience that trumps law.
docs.snippet: Catholic hospitals are now claiming a special right to conscience that trumps law.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the escalating conflict over the new federal requirement that employers include contraception coverage without a co-pay in the insurance plans they make available to their employees, opposition from the Catholic church and its allies is making headway with a powerfully appealing claim: that when conscience and government policy collide, conscience must prevail.
docs.abstract: Catholic hospitals are now claiming a special right to conscience that trumps law.
docs.snippet: Catholic hospitals are now claiming a special right to conscience that trumps law.

docs.abstract: A new report from the Guttmacher Institute says that pregnancy rates among teenagers dropped to a 30-year low.
docs.snippet: A new report from the Guttmacher Institute says that pregnancy rates among teenagers dropped to a 30-year low.

docs.lead_paragraph: Between 2006 and 2010, the number of unmarried teenagers between the ages of 15 and 19 who reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that they've had sex dropped below 50 percent. The C.D.C. described this as an actual drop in the number of teenagers having sex; the cynical addition of the word "reported" is mine: obviously the only way for the C.D.C. to determine whether those teenagers were sexually active (and how) was to ask them, and I've expressed my doubts about the resulting data.
docs.abstract: A new report from the Guttmacher Institute says that pregnancy rates among teenagers dropped to a 30-year low.
docs.snippet: A new report from the Guttmacher Institute says that pregnancy rates among teenagers dropped to a 30-year low.
